text:
James R. Walker, Professor

   

 

 

 

 

Education

1960 B.S., Northwestem State College, Natchitoches, LA (Chemistry/Bacteriology)

1963 Ph.D. University of Texas at Austin (Microbiology)

1965-67 Postdoctoral Fellow, Princeton University Princeton, NJ (Biochemical Science

Professional Experience:

1963-65 Racteriologist, U. S. Army Medical Lab, Europe, Landstuhl, West Ge

1967-71 Assistant Professor, Microbiology Dept. Univ. of Texas, Austin

1971-72 Adjunct Associate Professor (without salary), Microbiology Dept, Univ. of Texas
Medical School, Sun Antonio

1971-78 Associate Professor, Microbiology Dept., Univ. of Texas, Austin

1972.73 Research Associate of Konrad Bloch, Chemisty Dep... Harvard Univ.,
Cambridge, MA

1977 ASM Visiting Professor. Kederal Univ. of Rio de Janciro, Bravil

1978.81 Professor, Microbiology Dept, Univ of Texas, Austin,

1981-93 Professor and Chuirman, Microbiology Dept., Univ. of Texas, Austin

1993-present Professor, Microbiology Dept., Univ. of Texas, Austin
Bibliography (selected):

“Fletcher, G., C. A. Irwin, J. M. Henson, C. Fillingim, M, M, Malone and J. R. Walker.
Idemitication of the Escherichia cali cell division gene sep and organization of the cell divison-cell
Envelope genes in the sep-mur fisA-envA cluster as determined with specialized transducing %
bacteriophages. J. Bacteriol. 134 (1978) 91100,

Henson, J. M., H. Chu, C. A. Irwin and J. R. Walker. {solation and character
and dna¥ temperature-sensitive mutants of Escherichia coli. Genetics 92 (1979) I

 

 

  

  

“Inwin, C. A. G, Fletcher, C. Sills and J. R. Walker. Expression of the Escherichia coli ecll
division gene sep cloned in a A Charon phage. Science 206 (1979) 220-222

Walker, J. R., W. G. Haldenwang, J. Ramse
coli duaZ product, a polymerization protein,
protein. in The Initiation of DNA Replication

and A. Blinkowa. Evidence that the Escherichia
eraet i vivo with the dig prove, an ination
‘ed. D.S. Ray. 1981, p. 425-536.

  

Walker, J. RJ. A. Ramsey and W. G. Haldenwang. Interaction of the Escherichia coli daa
initiation protein with the polymerization dnaZ protein in vivo. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sei. USA 79
(1982) 3340-3344,

Blinkowa, A. W. G. Haldenwang, J. A. Ramsey, J. M. Henson, D. A. Mullin and J, R. Walker.
Physiological properties of cold-sensitive suppressor mutations of a temperature-sensitive draZ
mutant of Escherichia coli. J. Bacteriol. 153 (1983) 66-75.

Blinkowa, A. and J. R. Walker, Interactions of DNA replication factors in vivo as detected by
introduction of suppressor alleles of dnaA into other emperature-sensitive dna mutants. J
Bacteriol. 153 (1983) 535-538.

Mullin, D. A., C. L., Woldringh, J. M. Henson and J. R. Walker. Cloning ofthe Escherichia colt
dnaZX region and identification of its products. Mol. Gen, Genet. 192 (1983) 73-79.

Mullin, D. A..G. M, Garcia and J. R, Walker. An E. coli DNA fragment 118 base pairs in length
provides dna¥* complementing activity. Cell 37 (1984) 669-674,

Yin, KC., A. Blinkowa and J. R, Walker. Nucleotide sequence of the Escherichia coli
replication gene dnaZX. Nucl. Acids Res. 14 (1986) 6541-6549.

 

 

~~ 40045728.

summary: James R. Walker is a Professor of Microbiology at the University of Texas at Austin. He is the author of the book, "The Evolution of DNA," published by Oxford University Press. The book is based on a paper he wrote in 1979 for the journal Bacteriol. Science.
